alternate_names: Great War of the Spanish Succession

causes: The death of **Charles II of Spain** in 1700 without a clear heir
The contested succession to the Spanish throne between **Philip of Anjou** (grandson of King Louis XIV of France) and **Archduke Charles of Austria** (son of the Holy Roman Emperor)
The fear of a **united Bourbon monarchy** (Spain and France) that would upset the balance of power in Europe
events_leading_up_to_war: Philip V (Philip of Anjou) was chosen by Charles II of Spain as his heir in his will, but other European powers, including **Austria**, **Britain**, and **the Dutch Republic**, opposed the union of Spain and France under a single Bourbon monarch
In 1701, **France** and **Spain** declared war on the **Grand Alliance**, which included **Austria**, **Britain**, **the Dutch Republic**, and other powers

territorial_changes: Philip V remained King of Spain but renounced any claim to the French throne
Spain lost several territories, including the **Spanish Netherlands**, **Naples**, **Milan**, and **Gibraltar**, which was ceded to Britain
Austria gained territories in Italy and the Netherlands, expanding its influence in Europe

major_battles.name: Battle of Blenheim
major_battles.description: A decisive victory for the Grand Alliance under **John Churchill**, which crippled the French and Spanish forces and ensured British dominance in the war.

major_battles.name: Battle of Ramillies
major_battles.description: A significant victory by the Grand Alliance over French forces, marking another blow to French control in the Netherlands.

major_battles.name: Battle of Malplaquet
major_battles.description: The Grand Alliance inflicted heavy losses on the French, but at great cost, marking one of the bloodiest battles of the war.

terms: Philip V remained King of Spain but agreed to never unite the Spanish and French crowns
Spain lost significant territories, including **Gibraltar**, which was ceded to Britain
Austria gained parts of Italy and the Spanish Netherlands, solidifying its role as a great European power
Britain became a dominant maritime power with **Gibraltar**
impact: The balance of power in Europe was altered, with Britain gaining influence in the Mediterranean and Dutch control over parts of Europe weakened
The war confirmed the decline of **Spain's dominance** as a European power

long_term_effects: The rise of **Britain** as the premier naval power in the world
Austria’s political and military influence was solidified in Central Europe and Italy
The treaty created a new European order, which set the stage for future conflicts such as the **French Revolution**

economic: Britain’s control of **Gibraltar** gave it a vital strategic location for trade and naval dominance
The war strained European economies but led to the formation of colonial trading networks
political: The Treaty of Utrecht was pivotal in **shaping Europe’s borders and power dynamics** in the 18th century
The war marked the end of Spanish imperial expansion in Europe
social: The war caused significant disruption across Europe, leading to widespread famine, displacement, and social unrest in the territories affected
